numbered_ace_sentences: 1. Many students responded.
2. I thank all students who responded.
3. We had many catchy headlines.
4. The catchy headlines capture the main ideas of the graphs.
5. One catchy headline is "Sports: Diversity or Lies on Head Coaches of Color? The Color Spectrum in Sports".
6. Rosa wrote this catchy headline.
7. Rosa is from Los Angeles.
8. One catchy headline is "Behind the screen. Is it really diverse in the front office?".
9. Liam wrote this catchy headline.
10. Chen wrote this catchy headline.
11. Alex wrote this catchy headline.
12. One catchy headline is "The Colour of Sports".
13. Madison wrote this catchy headline.
14. Kai wrote this catchy headline.
15. Madison is from Winnipeg.
16. Kai is from Winnipeg.
17. Winnipeg is in Manitoba.
18. Manitoba is in Canada.
19. One catchy headline is "The Roles People of Color Hold in Sports Leagues".
20. Lauren wrote this catchy headline.
21. Lauren is from Academy of Saint Elizabeth.
22. Academy of Saint Elizabeth is in Morristown.
23. Morristown is in New Jersey.
24. One catchy headline is "The Divide in Diversity: The Gap Between Diverse Athletes and Coaches".
25. OBBI wrote this catchy headline.
26. OBBI is from Eden Prairie High School.
27. Eden Prairie High School is in Minnesota.
28. You can continue to post responses.
29. Please check back by Friday, Feb. 5.
30. On Friday, Feb. 5, you can see the Reveal.
31. The Reveal has a link to the original New York Times article.
32. The Reveal has some questions about the map.
33. The Reveal has a few Stat Nuggets.
34. Please visit our archive.
35. In our archive, you can see all graphs in this series.
36. The URL tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs identifies the archive.
37. Please view our archives.
38. The archives link to all past releases.

45. Sharon Hessney signs off.
46. Corey Andreasen signs off.
47. Sharon Hessney is from Boston.
48. Sharon Hessney thinks that progress in diversifying professional sports has been too little and too slow.
49. Corey Andreasen is a grade 5 mathematics teacher.
50. Corey Andreasen works at the American School of the Hague.
51. The American School of the Hague is in the Netherlands.
52. Corey Andreasen thinks that the patterns in these graphs indicate a much wider problem.
